content.content:
People who have a growth mindset believe that they can develop talents by working hard and learning from others. People who have a fixed mindset believe that they are either born with a talent or not. 

Fixed versus growth mindset

content.subheading: A manager tells you that you’re not qualified for a job you wanted. Do you:
items: Feel defensive and defeated and decide that you need to lower your expectations, or
See this as feedback that you need new skills and sign up for a leadership class

content.content:
The first response shows what experts call a fixed mindset, while the second response shows a growth mindset, or a learning mindset. (Source: Harvard Business Review) 

Benefits of a growth mindset
A growth mindset is key to achieving goals. Developing a growth mindset can help you stay motivated — and even thrive — when you face roadblocks. Studies even show that brains benefit when working through challenges and fixing mistakes. (Source: Mindset Scholars Network) 

Staying in a growth mindset isn’t always easy. It can be especially challenging during a job search, when things are uncertain and you’re repeatedly putting yourself out there.  But developing a growth mindset is worth the effort.

items: Focus on improvement. Instead of focusing on how qualified or smart you are, think about what steps you can take to do something better.

See challenges as opportunities. Don’t let yourself hide from something because you’re scared you will fail. Instead, try to get comfortable with the idea that you will likely fail at first. Then keep going.

Value learning over approval. Learning opportunities are always available. Approval may not be. Look for an opportunity to do something well, and let that be your motivation rather than someone else’s approval.
Study your failures. Failures and rejections are some of the best opportunities to grow. Identify what happened and how you can change in the future.

content.content:
Situation: Not getting a job

Fixed mindset: I will never get a job. 
Growth mindset: That interview was good practice. I learned that I need to practice answering questions, like why I want the job, in a clearer way.

Situation: Not getting a promotion 

Fixed mindset: I’m not good enough to be a manager. 
Growth mindset: I didn’t get the promotion. I will ask my supervisor what skills I need to work on, and what I can do to be considered for future promotions.
Reflect on how you react to setbacks and think about ways to practice a growth mindset.
